div1.p: Martinez asserts the Book of Chilam Balam is not an accurate source of history.

div1.head: Letter fragment from J. Martinez H. to [Henry Rose Carter], July 13, 1922
div1.p: Part of Dr. Martinez' Letter of July 13/22.

“We must not insist on the accuracy of the Books of Chilam Balam
as a source of real history. The Tizimin, on folio 15, page 29, refers,
on the 4 ahau, to the same prediction: “xe-kik, u cuch katun” (“blood
vomit is the outcome of the katun”) “te tu uich can ahau katun vale, uchei
maya-cimlal, ocnal-kuchil,” (in the transcourse of the katun four ahau,
probably, took place the calamity or pestilence called “maya-cimlal,” (“the
pestilence of the Mayas”), and “ocnal-kuchil” (when so many died that the
buzzards entered the houses to eat the corpses;) (“such statement was
made by the High Priest); “bay bin uchpahal tu vuudz (1) tu caten, ti cu
tal tu cuch-habil, bay yalci ahkin chilan tu cuch-katun can ahau vale,”
(so it will again take place, when it turns again, it is indicated in the
in the course of the yearly events, as was predicted by the High Priest, as
the coming events in the course of the katun four ahau, probably.”
(Red underlines, is the maya text: black underlines, my translation.)

The same entry of the ritual is made on page 33, fol 17, which
seems to me a brief ritualistic recital of the first just mentioned.

On page 99 of the Book of Chilam Balam of Chumayel, (Philadelphia
edition, University Museum. 1913) we have similar statement on which
which
2
Bishop Carrillo laid so much stress (P. 19-20, “Carta sobre la Historia
de la Biebre Amarilla, Merida. 1892”), although this katun four ahau
corresponds to the year of 1740 according to this book.

The Tizimin was copied in 1593, from some document or Codex then
in existence; others recopied the same document several times and in dif-
ferent epochs, making additions, errors, omissions, intercallations etc.

If according to Landa, katun “11 ahau” began in 1541, katun 4 ahau
began A. D. 1480; in 1500, 2 ahau; in 1520, 13 ahau. A katun 4 ahau
will take place or recur every 256 years (13 katuns of 7200 days). I
would suggest A. D. 2480 as the best probable date for the “xekik” record.

(1) P. S. I am afraid that the word uadz (the fourth time) should be
uudz as in this first instance no such fourth time of xekik is mentioned,
but uudz, the doubling or sifting movement of the katun: caten (again)
is written twice; it should not be read can ten (the fourth time), but
caten (twice, again).

(2) P. S. The calamity “maya-cimlal” and its outcome “ona-kuchil,” is
mentioned as an occurrence which happened in katun 4 ahau by the Tizimin
and Chumayel Chronicles, pages 142, 156, 168 of Brinton's book: “The

Maya Chronicles,” Phila. 1882. All this evidence points out xe-kik as
being the cause of the pestilence about 1480-1500. The 11 Chumayel
Chronicle points out as the 5th. year of 4 ahau about 1485.
